description: High entropy domain query (youtu.be) detected, possibly used to bypass DNS filters; high entropy often indicates domain generation algorithms (DGAs) or obfuscated C2 channels.
High entropy domain (youtu.be) forwarded to public DNS server (8.8.8.8), continuing pattern of DNS activity possibly tied to evasion or DGA.
Another host querying the same high entropy domain (youtu.be), which could indicate shared malware behavior or C2 beaconing attempt.
Host forwards DNS query for high entropy domain (youtu.be), indicative of persistent C2 traffic or misclassified domain.
DNS reply received for youtu.be with legitimate IP address, suggesting it's likely normal traffic and not a malicious domain.
Repeat of previous DNS reply for youtu.be, confirming likely benign traffic to a legitimate service (YouTube).
Low frequency of A record queries for domain 'mail.price.fox.org' compared to expected volume; could indicate targeted DNS reconnaissance or exfiltration.
Repeated IMAP login disconnections with no authentication attempts from suspicious IP; could be scanning or scripted login probes.
Same login anomaly logged in system log; supports brute force or reconnaissance of IMAP service from same remote IP.
Third record of failed IMAP login session without user info; increased confidence in credential enumeration or service discovery.
Reverse DNS lookup failed for IP 192.168.130.77, may indicate scanning or spoofed address.
Repeat of reverse DNS lookup failure, indicating potential probing or enumeration.
Client 192.168.130.77 denied by server configuration trying to access /var/www/html; may be probing for accessible endpoints.
Client 172.17.130.196 denied by server configuration while trying to access /var/www/html; indicates probing behavior.
Repeated reverse DNS lookup failure for IP 192.168.130.77; further indicates scanning activity.
Unexpected TLS packet received during handshake; commonly seen in misconfigured or active scanning behavior.
Yet another reverse DNS failure for same IP, corroborating scanning attempt.
Nmap Scripting Engine identified in user-agent; accessing nmaplowercheck endpoint with 403 response shows scanning attempt.
Nmap Scripting Engine user-agent performing POST to /sdk; unusual method for Nmap, but 403 confirms server-side detection.
GET / with HTTP/1.0 and 403 response, commonly seen in version probing and fingerprinting scans.
POST request to /sdk returned 403 with Nmap user-agent indicating possible automated probing or service detection
POST request to /sdk with 403 status and Nmap Scripting Engine user-agent suggests reconnaissance activity
Access denied to /var/www/html/HNAP1 implies scanning or probing for specific vulnerable paths
Denied access to /var/www/html/HNAP1 by same source as previous log, indicating enumeration of known endpoints
Request denied for /var/www/html/HNAP1 by 172.17.130.196 supports enumeration of known firmware vulnerabilities
Access denied to generic root directory /var/www/html/ could indicate directory traversal or discovery scans
Another denied access to /var/www/html/ by different IP supports horizontal scanning behavior
403 response to GET request on Akismet plugin path with WPScan user-agent suggests vulnerability enumeration
HEAD request to WordPress analytics plugin path from WPScan with 404 response indicates plugin enumeration
HEAD request to animate-it plugin with WPScan user-agent and 404 result shows probing for vulnerable plugins
Use of HEAD request and WPScan user-agent indicates automated scanning for vulnerable WordPress plugins.
HEAD request to a known plugin path with WPScan user-agent shows probing for vulnerable plugin presence.
Access attempt to a WordPress plugin using a non-standard HEAD method from WPScan tool.
Request to a different plugin endpoint with WPScan indicates plugin enumeration activity.
HEAD request with WPScan user-agent for a less common plugin path, further suggesting plugin discovery.
Scans for plugin using a HEAD request format to avoid downloading full responses, consistent with enumeration.
Attempt to discover presence of plugin via HEAD request shows scanning behavior.
Request targets known vulnerable script (timthumb.php), a common target in old WordPress themes.
HEAD request probing different path variants of vulnerable timthumb.php script.
Malformed or double filename suggests automated bruteforce script targeting timthumb vulnerability.
Use of 'HEAD' request method targeting a vulnerable PHP script (timthumb.php) via WPScan user-agent
Use of 'HEAD' request method on suspicious PHP script (thumb.php) commonly exploited in WordPress themes
Attempt to access .htpasswd file, commonly used for storing credentials
Attempt to access obfuscated version of .htpasswd file using altered filename (.htpasswd_)
Suspicious request to endpoint with unexpected character '@', often used in fuzzing or traversal attempts
Suspicious request with character '~', possibly probing for hidden administrative folders (~adm)
Request for missing PHP script (info.php) in a WordPress directory suggests scanning for known vulnerable scripts
Use of '+' in URL path (lost+found), indicative of automated scanners probing for non-standard paths
Probing for phpinfo.php script, often used by attackers to gain environment information
Suspicious request to path with '~webmaster' suggests probing for administrative resources
The request contains a tilde (~) character in a suspicious path likely probing for backup files or directories, indicating directory enumeration or path discovery.
Attempt to access a directory without a default index file; this often indicates directory enumeration or information gathering.
Access attempt to hidden .hta file possibly for privilege escalation or remote code execution; this may indicate probing for server misconfiguration.
Request to a language directory resulted in a 301 redirect, indicating path probing; part of recursive directory enumeration.
Unusual character (+) in a URL, indicative of fuzzing or directory enumeration probing uncommon paths.
301 redirect from plugin directory indicates scanning for web application components or plugins.
Attempt to access phpinfo.php which can disclose sensitive environment information; common technique in reconnaissance.
301 redirect from skins directory implies probing for components or configuration of web applications.
Request to themes directory with 301 indicates scanning for available themes, typical during reconnaissance of WordPress sites.
Request for a non-existent PHP file in a theme directory; may indicate attempts to exploit theme vulnerabilities or RFI/LFI.
Request to a potentially non-existent path using uncommon character '+' in URL indicates directory or file enumeration
Request to a non-existent PHP file in WordPress theme directory hints at reconnaissance or scanning for vulnerable files
Attempt to access phpinfo.php suggests reconnaissance for server information exposure
HTTP 403 response to a request for a JavaScript plugin folder is indicative of probing for administrative or restricted resources
Access to suspicious URL containing '~logs' implies probing for hidden or backup logs
Attempt to access path '~lp' under admin image directory indicates automated discovery of hidden or sensitive resources
URL with '~mail' path suggests probe for potential webmail interfaces or related data
Suspicious access to '~nobody' path implies probing for system-level or placeholder user directories
Use of '~operator' path is consistent with enumeration of sensitive or system-named resources
Access attempt to info.php file suggests probing for environment disclosure files within an admin image path
Request to a non-existent resource containing unusual characters (+), likely probing for sensitive or forgotten directories.
Attempt to access phpinfo.php suggests attacker trying to gather environment info or test for PHP execution.
403 Forbidden response from accessing a sensitive theme directory; indicative of enumeration or access probe.
Access attempt to .hta file may indicate probing for hidden scripts or Windows-specific backdoor tricks.
Attempt to access .htpasswd file is a well-known vector to steal credentials or password hashes.
Suspicious request for variant of .htpasswd (.htpasswd_) suggests probing for backup/misnamed sensitive files.
Access attempt to path with '@' character likely aims to test for unconventional or hidden resources.
Use of '~adm' in path implies probing for hidden admin interfaces or user directories.
Access attempt to '~admin' path further supports enumeration of admin-related endpoints.
Attempt to access .htaccess file blocked by configuration, common in attempts to bypass or understand server protections.
Access attempt to hidden .htaccess file, typically targeted during enumeration or reconnaissance
Attempt to access .htpasswd file, commonly targeted to extract credentials or verify misconfigurations
Access to modified/backup variant of .htpasswd (.htpasswd_), likely part of brute-force discovery attempt
Request to non-existent admin.php file, often used in probing for admin panels or sensitive scripts
Probing for index.php in admin directory, likely part of directory brute-force or recon activity
Access to a suspicious .php file with high-entropy encoded parameters, indicating potential web shell or backdoor
High-entropy GET request to previously identified suspicious PHP file, possibly retrieving encoded data or payload
Another access to same PHP web shell file, indicating ongoing control or exfiltration attempts
Unusual spike in POST method usage from headless browser, possibly automated polling or brute force attack
Sharp CPU usage deviation suggests potential resource abuse, could indicate crypto mining or DoS attempt
Unusual DNS query frequency detected to mmx-ds.cdn.whatsapp.net from internal host, possibly indicating C2 traffic using DNS.
Unusual HTTP request method frequency from internal host suggests scanning or fingerprinting behavior.
High entropy URL with obfuscated PHP filename and base64-like payload in GET parameter indicates a potential web shell upload or execution.
Successful 'su' command from www-data to user 'phopkins' indicates a potential privilege escalation from web user to system user.
New terminal session initiated by www-data to 'phopkins' shows unexpected lateral or privilege transition.
Session opened by UID 33 (www-data) for user 'phopkins' could signify abuse of su command for persistence or lateral movement.
New authentication log entry where www-data authenticates as 'phopkins' via /bin/su, possibly indicating credential compromise.
Account log confirms successful user switch to 'phopkins' using /bin/su, reinforcing possible credential abuse.
Credential acquisition using PAM setcred for user 'phopkins' by UID 33 points to session token or privilege elevation.
User session start using /bin/su indicates an elevated or persistent session, especially notable due to web user origin.
